title: How to explain your research to a layman when meeting for the first time - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t. Like most mathematicians (if not most researchers), I work off in an obscure corner of the intellectual universe. I do strange things with abstract stuff like binary trees and matrices and recursion and topology that most laymen have no exposure to and don’t care about. Most people don’t even know that university professors do research. Most people would correctly interpret even a cursory description of “my research” as a flood of meaningless buzzwords, which I’m just throwing at them to make myself sound smart. That’s just rude. I generally talk about more relatable stuff, like teaching, or office politics, or my kids, or travel. Everyone’s had teachers, everyone’s office has politics, everyone has a family, and we’re probably on a plane. Sometimes, especially if the person I’m talking to solves problems for a living (for example: doctor, teacher, electrician, auto mechanic, blacksmith, video editor, portrait artist), we can talk about the problem-solving process. But few people outside the Ivory Tower have dealt with Referee #2 or fought the Notation Demons, and even fewer have ever tried to (or wanted to) understand the role of homology in computing strictly convex drawings of essentially 3-connected graphs on the torus. (See what I mean?) On the extremely rare occasion that someone I’ve just met actually asks about my research (beyond the level of “I design algorithms”), I usually start with something vague like “It’s pretty abstract. I draw a lot of donuts.” or “Did you ever play Asteroids? Imagine some of the rocks are connected by rubber bands.”

If you want to explain your research to a layperson you’re meeting for the first time, talk to your mother about it! I think this is a great question. Before we start, let’s define the parameters of our conversational setting. If it’s a random layperson, it would be extremely arrogant of me to start talking about my research. I’d rather talk about something that’s interesting for both of us. That said, it’s inevitable that you would run into situations where people do not have a lot of idea about your field of study, but you’re still expected to explain your research to them. This is particularly relevant in a corporate research lab where you’d be collaborating with people from engineering, management, marketing and much more. Back when my advisor was a graduate student, he had to deal with company CEOs directly and present his work, to secure funding for his doctoral research at his university. Even if you’re presenting your paper in a conference, it is always a good idea to motivate the problem in layperson words. This makes the presentation more powerful as most attendees would have something to gain from it. So, knowing how to talk about your work at a high level so that it’s interesting to laypeople, is always a good skill to have in your armory. For me, one thing that really helped develop this skill was talking to my mother about my research. My mother’s always been inquisitive about what I do. Unfortunately, she has an Economics background and she doesn’t get any details whatsoever. Talking to her has really helped me develop a perspective on what a layperson can relate to and what the best way of explaining my work would be. A good way of motivating your work to a layperson would be to keep things on a high/abstract level. A good strategy at first would be to talk about an application or a natural event that they’re bound to experience. For example, in my case I say, “When you go to a party, you don’t have a problem talking and listening to your friend even when there are several people talking around you.” Now that they have an idea about the application, you can explain the research problem on a high level again. So I say something along the lines of, “Humans are very good at it, but a computer would get utterly confused. So, my goal is to teach a computer to do that.” If the other person finds the problem interesting, I’ve noticed they often get back with questions that are on a high level again. Now, answering these questions is a lot easier since they set the technicality of the conversation at their comfort level and you just respond to questions. Original question: How do you explain your research to a layman when meeting for the first time?
